stem: A 16-year-old client with anorexia nervosa is being monitored for cardiovascular stability. Based on the documentation in the Serial Orthostatic & Cardiac Surveillance Log, what is the most urgent action the nurse should take?

options.text: Maintain strict bed rest and notify the provider of unstable vitals.
Encourage the client to increase fluid intake to 3,000 mL/day.
Administer STAT IV Atropine to raise the heart rate.
Re-check the blood pressure in the Trendelenburg position.

rationale.correct: The client is exhibiting critical cardiovascular instability (a1). In anorexia nervosa, heart muscle atrophy can lead to severe bradycardia and hypotension. The significant drop in heart rate upon standing (from 40 to 32 bpm) and a systolic blood pressure of 72 mmHg indicate a failure of the autonomic nervous system to compensate, placing the client at high risk for syncope and cardiac arrest. Strict bed rest is essential until the client is stabilized through rehydration and nutritional support. Notifying the provider is crucial for further intervention.
clinicalPearls: Orthostatic vital signs: In a healthy individual, heart rate typically increases upon standing. In severe anorexia nervosa, the heart rate may paradoxically decrease or fail to rise due to the heart's inability to handle the increased workload.
Hospitalization criteria for anorexia nervosa often include: heart rate less than 40 bpm, systolic blood pressure less than 90 mmHg, or temperature less than 96Â°F.
Mottled skin and prolonged capillary refill time (CRT) suggest poor systemic perfusion (peripheral vasoconstriction).

questionTrap.trap: Assuming Atropine (a3) is the appropriate treatment for chronic starvation-induced bradycardia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Atropine is indicated for acute, symptomatic bradycardia (e.g., heart block). In anorexia nervosa, the heart is physically weakened due to atrophy; pharmacological stimulation may be ineffective or dangerous. The priority is ensuring safety (bed rest) and initiating medical stabilization.

mnemonic.title: Heart of Stone
mnemonic.expansion: Small heart, Slow beat. BP low, Stay on seat (Bed rest).

exhibits.title: Nurses Notes
exhibits.content: 1215: Client reports significant 'lightheadedness' and 'shaking' when attempting to walk to the bathroom. Skin is cool and mottled in lower extremities. Capillary refill time is 4 seconds.

exhibits.title: 12-Lead EKG
exhibits.content: Result: Sinus Bradycardia. Heart rate 32 bpm. Prolonged QT interval (0.48 seconds). No ectopy noted.
